subject: Productivity
title: Second-Order Thinking
description: A short lesson to help you apply Second-Order Thinking.

hook.text: Banning plastic bags seems obvious. But paper bags use four times more energy to produce. Second-order effects matter.

buildup.text: First-order thinking asks: what happens next? Second-order thinking asks: and then what happens after that?

discovery.text: Howard Marks uses this in investing: obvious moves are priced in. The edge comes from seeing further ahead.

twist.text: Most people stop at the first consequence. Strategic thinkers trace the chain two or three steps deeper.

climax.text: Second-order thinking prevents unintended consequences and reveals hidden opportunities others miss.

punchline.text: Think beyond the next move. Think three moves ahead.

quiz.question: What does second-order thinking ask?
options: What happens after the immediate consequence
